Happy Birthday, USMC

whatever
Published on Nov 9, 2025 by Lehman · 3 min read

On 10 November, 1775, the United States Marine Corps was formed in Tun Tavern, Philadelphia, PA, with Samuel Nicholas as the first USMC Commandant.

I stepped onto the MCRD San Diego yellow footprints in September of 1968, and I was on active duty until September of 1972.

“Boot Camp Graduation Portrait, Q4 1968”

The Vietnam war was still active at the time, but I was never in country, and I did not see combat. This was a very good thing, as I am a mediocre warrior and an excellent target…

Because I enlisted for four years, the Marine Corps guaranteed me a school 1, so I spent most of 1969 in San Diego earning my MOS 2841 Ground Radio Repairman certificate2.

“San Diego, CA Electronics School, 1969”

I repaired the gear at Marine Base 29 Palms, CA during most of 1970,

“29 Palms CA, 1970”

and for the remainder of my hitch I performed various security duties at Marine Barracks Yokosuka Naval Base, Japan

“Marine Barracks, Yokosuka, 1971 - 1972”

“Marine Barracks, Yokosuka, 1971 - 1972”

The Corps was a microcosm of American culture during the late 1960s: there was an undercurrent of racial tension, rampant drug and alchohol use, and a general discontent with established authority. I confess to succumbing to some of those influences, but in my defense my DD-214 shows that I was awarded the Good Conduct Medal, a Letter of Recognition (I placed first at the 29 Palms NCO School), I consistently qualified as a Rifle Sharpshooter, I attained the rank of Sergeant within three years, and I was Honorably Discharged, so I wasn’t a total shitbird, to use the vernacular of the times. I could have been a better Marine, and I regret that, but I don’t know how much more could have been expected out of a 21 year old kid from Detroit…

What did I learn during my active duty time? I learned that all governments lie. All the time. About everything. As a result, my social and political philosophies align more with Smedley Butler rather than Chesty Puller.

I also learned that I have difficulty taking orders from people who are my intellectual inferiors; since that time I have endeavoured to surround myself with friends, family and colleagues who are smarter than me. I am pleased to report that I have been successful in that effort.

I also learned that good people - and bad people - come in all shapes, sizes, colors and nationalities. We must constantly strive not to hate in the plural, although that can be very difficult at times.

I have had no interaction with the Marine Corps since my active duty days, so I’m not sure how badly the Corps has been infected with the woke and gay mind virus, but if the American People ever decide to re-embrace the values of Duty, Honor and Country, I am confident that the United States Marine Corps will lead by example.

And so to all Marines past, present and future: Semper Fi and God Speed!

Footnotes

  1. But I didn’t read the fine print - the Corps guaranteed me a school, but there was no guarantee that I would be assigned to those duties. You go where you are told to go, you do what you are told to do, and you only have two choices: 1) “Aye Aye, Sir”, or 2) go directly to jail. ↩

  2. MOS = Military Occupational Speciality ↩
